metadata.case_name: Radhey Shyam Sharma v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioner appointed as a Telegraphist by the Post Master General Nagpur in 1949.
In July 1960, petitioner serving as an officiating Teleprinter Supervisor at Jaipur.
Employees of the Posts and Telegraphs Department went on strike from the midnight of July 11, 1960 throughout India, including at Jaipur.

Petitioner was on duty on July 11, 1960 from 12 noon to 8 p.m. After duty, he went to the dormitory, fell asleep as tired, woke up at about 11:30 p.m., wanted to go home but was arrested by police as one of the demonstrators outside in connection with the strike.
Petitioner arrested under the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, No. 1 of 1960.
On July 13, 1960, petitioner suspended on the ground that a criminal charge was pending against him; criminal charge withdrawn on July 18, 1960.

On July 21, 1960, charge-sheet served: Shri Radhey Shyam Sharma, ICS Telegraphist, CTO Jaipur committed gross misconduct in that on the midnight of the 11th July 1960, he took part in a demonstration in furtherance of the strike of the P.T. Employees in violation of the orders dated 8-7-1960 issued by the Government of India under the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, 1960 (1 of 1960) prohibiting strike in any postal, telegraph or telephone Service.
Inquiry made by the Post Master General, Central Services Nagpur; enquiry officer found petitioner guilty of the charge.
Notice issued to show cause why the penalty of reduction in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years affecting the future increments be imposed.

Post Master General ordered pay of petitioner reduced in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years and on restoration the period of reduction was not to operate to postpone his future increments.
Petitioner filed appeal to the Director General, Posts and Telegraphs; Director General directed further evidence to be taken; no further evidence given by Department; appeal rejected on merits.
Petitioner was the Secretary of the local union of the employees of the Department.
Petitioner's duty finished at 8 p.m. on July 11, 1960 but he stayed on in the dormitory till 11:30 p.m., which was half an hour before the strike was to commence.
Demonstration held in connection with the strike by employees at 11:30 p.m. on July 11, 1960; petitioner took part and was arrested amongst the demonstrators.
Central Government issued order dated July 8, 1960 under s.3 of the Ordinance prohibiting strike in the Department.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.3, 4 and 5 of the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, No. 1 of 1960 are ultra vires as they contravene sub-clauses (a) and (b) of Art. 19(1).
Whether the punishment imposed upon the petitioner is violative of his fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(b).
Whether there was any evidence on which it could be found that the charge against the petitioner had been proved.

petitioner_arguments.text: Punishment imposed is violative of fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(b) and should be quashed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(b); Kameshwar Prasad v. State of Bihar; O. Ghosh v. E.X. Joseph

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss. 3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are ultra vires as they contravene sub-clauses (a) and (b) of Art. 19(1).
There was no evidence on which it could be found that the charge against the petitioner had been proved.

respondent_arguments.text: The Ordinance is perfectly constitutional and does not violate any fundamental rights.
The two cases relied upon by the petitioner (Kameshwar Prasad and O. Ghosh) are of no assistance as they were concerned with R.4-A and Rule 4-B of the Central Civil Services (Conduct) Rules, 1955.
There was evidence on which the authorities concerned could find the charge proved against the petitioner.

court_reasoning.text: There is no fundamental right to strike, and the Ordinance provides with respect to illegal strikes; it does not restrict freedom of speech and expression or right to assemble peaceably and without arms under Art. 19(1)(a) and (b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: A perusal of Art. 19(1) shows that there is no fundamental right to strike.

court_reasoning.text: Kameshwar Prasad case related to R.4-A of Bihar rules prohibiting demonstrations; held violative insofar as demonstrations but valid for strikes. O.K. Ghosh concerned Central Conduct Rules rr.4-A, 4-B; did not deal with the Ordinance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The charge is based entirely on the Ordinance and has no connection with rr.4-A and 4-B.

court_reasoning.text: Charge is for gross misconduct by taking part in demonstration in furtherance of illegal strike under ss.3,4,5 of Ordinance; strike was illegal per order dated 8-7-1960; acting in furtherance punishable under s.5.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The charge does not deal with freedom of speech or assembly but acting in furtherance of illegal strike.

court_reasoning.text: Undisputed facts: petitioner Secretary of union, duty ended 8pm but stayed till 11:30pm, demonstration at 11:30pm half hour before strike, arrested amongst demonstrators; sufficient evidence to find charge proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If on these undisputed facts the authorities came to the conclusion that the petitioner acted in furtherance of the strike... it cannot be said that there was no evidence.

holdings.text: Ss.3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are not violative of fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(a) and (b); Ordinance is valid.
Punishment not violative of Arts. 19(1)(a) and (b) as charge based on acting in furtherance of illegal strike under Ordinance, not speech or assembly.
There was evidence on which authorities could find charge proved.

precedents_cited.case_name: All India Bank Employees Association v. National Industrial Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Held there is no fundamental right to strike.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kameshwar Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Related to R.4-A of Bihar Government Servants Conduct Rules prohibiting demonstrations; violative of Art.19(1)(a),(b) for demonstrations but valid for strikes.

precedents_cited.case_name: O. K. Ghosh v. E. X. Joseph
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerned rr.4-A, 4-B of Central Civil Services Conduct Rules; did not deal with the Ordinance or similar charge.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32 for enforcement of fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(a),(b); restrictions under cls.2,3.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, No. 1 of 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits strikes in essential services including postal/telegraph/telephone; makes strikes illegal; punishes commencement, participation, instigation or acting in furtherance.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Conduct) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in cited cases but charge not based on these; distinguished.

outcome.summary: The petition under Art.32 challenging the punishment of reduction in time scale as violative of Art.19(1)(a),(b), Ordinance validity, and lack of evidence is dismissed; Ordinance upheld as constitutional, charge proved on evidence, punishment not violative of fundamental rights.

key_quotes.text: A perusal of Art. 19(1) shows that there is no fundamental right to strike
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding rejecting challenge to Ordinance and punishment.

key_quotes.text: The Ordinance thus has nothing to do with restricting the fundamental rights enshrined in sub-cls. (a) and (b) of Art. 19(1)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dismisses ultra vires claim under Art.19.

key_quotes.text: If on these undisputed facts the authorities came to the conclusion that the petitioner acted in furtherance of the strike... it cannot be said that there was no evidence
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds finding of guilt based on circumstantial evidence.
